animal_concentrations.Value: Analysis of liver samples of 15 common eider (Somateria mollissima) from the western Gulf of Finland (northern Baltic Sea) collected in August-September, 2002, showed that eider liver samples contained 3 to 180 ug NODLN/kg dry weight and 0.1 to 5.8 ug nodularin/liver (dry wt)(1).

Thirty eiders (Somateria mollissima) were caught from the western Gulf of Finland between September 2002 and October 2004. Eiders from April to June 2003 were found dead. Nodularin was detected in 27 eiders; liver samples contained nodularin up to approximately 200 ug/kg dry weight and muscle samples at approximately 20 ug/kg dry weight(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Engstroem-Ost J et al; J Exp Mar Biol Ecol 276: 95-107 (2002) (2) Ibelings BW, Havens KE; in Cyanobacterial toxins. Springer Science and Business Media, LLC. New York, NY: Chpt 32: 706-732 (2008). Available from, https://www.epa.gov/cyano_habs_symposium/monograph.html as of July 20, 2009.
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Seasonally variable concentrations of nodularin toxin have been detected in the field depending on the size and location of cynaobacterial and algae blooms. Nodularin was detected in three-spined sticklebacks (35-170 ng/g), salmon/herring (2-6 ng/g), cod/flounder (25-400 ng/g. Mysid shrimp where also shown to accumulate nodularin in the laboratory(1). Aquatic biota exposed through natural routes have also shown concentrations of nodularin. Nodularin concentrations in flounder were 0.82-6.37 ug/g dried liver, in mussels 2.15 ug/g, and clams 0.1-0.13 ug/g(2).

Nodularin concentrations in Northern Baltic sea flounder livers collected on July 11, August 15, August 22, September 5, September 19, and September 27, 2002 were 250, 50, 15, 20 100, and 75 ug/kg dry weight, respectively. Sampling was conducted in response to intense cyanobacterial blooms in the Gulf of Finland in July-August 2002, consisting of Nodularia spumigena, Aphanizomenon sp., and Anabaena sp. Nodularin has been found to bioaccumulate in the Northern Baltic sea flounder due to their consumption of blue mussels(1).

Eleven roach and 15 flounders were caught from the western Gulf of Finland (northern Baltic Sea) between September 2002 and October 2004. Nodularin was detected in nine roach and eight flounders. Roach liver samples 20 to 900 ug nodularin/kg dry weight and muscle samples 2 to 200 ug nodularin/kg dry weight; flounder liver samples approximately 5 to 1,100 ug nodularin/kg dry weight and muscle samples up to 100 ug nodularin/kg dry weight(1).
